newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Senate bill on "comp time" stalled.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Senate bill on "comp time" stalled.

text.p: The U.S. Senate was deadlocked Wednesday over efforts to reach agreement on a "workplace flexiblity" bill that would allow workers to take time off rather than receive overtime pay.
Republicans, who sponsored the bill, say it gives hourly wage workers, especially working mothers, more flexibility and enables them to better balance work and family responsibilities.

It would give workers the option to take compensatory time instead of overtime pay, a choice that government workers and salaried employees already have. It would also allow for "flex-time", for instance, by letting an employee work longer hours for nine days and get every other Friday off.

Democrats say they agree with that general goal but that this specific bill gave flexibility to the employer and not the worker. They said it essentially abolished the 40-hour workweek and could lead to coercion of workers to take the comp time even if they wanted and needed the overtime pay.
Democrats, joined by a few Republicans, for the second time in less than a month defeated a move to cut off debate on the bill.
"The flexibility needs to be with the worker. It's the workers themselves that need to choose," said Sen. Mary Landrieu, a Louisiana Democrat.
Lead sponsor Sen. John Ashcroft, a Missouri Republican, said the public strongly supported his bill and he still hoped to reach some type of agreement with the Democrats.
